channel.title: Forensics on nullvm
channel.description: Recent content in Forensics on nullvm

item.title: PicoCTF Writeup #530
item.description:
Challenge: Riddle Registry

Every digital file has a story to tell — some louder than others. In this picoCTF forensics challenge, our mission was simple on paper (pun intended): find the flag hidden inside a PDF file.

Of course, as any seasoned Linux user knows, “simple” often means “prepare for several hours of creative command-line archaeology.”

The Setup

Challenge: A suspicious-looking PDF file Goal: Find the flag Category: Forensics

Opening the file showed nothing but Lorem Ipsum text and some odd blank spaces. That’s usually a hint in CTFs — if you can’t see it, it’s probably hidden somewhere else.

item.title: PicoCTF Writeup #505
item.description:
PicoCTF Writeup – Forensics Disk Image

Challenge: Disk, disk, sleuth!

Description: Can you find the flag in this disk image? Download the disk image here.

First Thoughts

This challenge was tagged forensics, which usually means poking around filesystems, memory dumps, or raw disk images. The goal is to extract hidden information — in this case, the flag.

I grabbed the disk image (disko-1.dd) and started experimenting.

Initial Attempts

My first instinct was to take a look at the raw hex using xxd:
